text: hi everyone
bigelow here the internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new pallbearer album foundations of
burden these guys are an arkansas metal
band who is fantastically good at
picking hilariously depressing album
titles here's their last full-length lp
their debut full-length lp sorrow and
extinction came out in
enjoyed it quite a bit when it dropped
initially i reviewed it and today i'm
still somewhat fond of it and this lp of
theirs is a traditional doom metal album
it features five slow
heavy dreary metal songs with a strong
sense of melody and a very eerie and
occult vibe think saint vitus think
black sabbath but there's something in
pallbearer's music that also reminds me
of bands like jethro tull it just feels
like they listen to just a touch of
progressive rock enough for it to turn
up in their melody writing in their
vocals this first full-length lp was far
from
reinventing the wheel but i thought the
production was really good maybe the
vocals and the lead guitars were a
little buried but the riffs were very
heavy and bassy just gargantuan and the
melodies on this record record lead
guitar melodies i would say are where
pallbearer gets most of its musical
power to me this record had just about
everything it needed going for it except
variety
varying ideas this album to me while
very good in parts is kind of like a
monotone monolith and from here i was
definitely looking forward to whatever
the band would do in the future given
that it involved maybe a little bit more
exploration with their sound maybe
experimenting with some different metal
styles or even writing some more concise
songs even too
direct straight into the point songs
could really do wonders to break up a
five song track list i have no real
issue with any one song on this album or
really any one song on paul bearer's
newest album too but how can all these
slow
epic melodic tracks feel significant or
dramatic or stand out if all they're
backed up against are slow melodic epic
tracks and this album is even longer
than its predecessor and the band does
not really spend this extra time
diversifying their sound not really this
album is a sequel to the first one in in
like almost every sense from the
sluggish pacing of these songs to the
melodies to the sort of buried vocals
and again no song is really horrible on
its own again we are getting these
haunting fiery guitar leads the most
sinister of which end up on the very
last song here we get these thick and
bassy heavy riffs monster drums and
despite being 10 minutes in length
nearly every song here is pretty
engaging from beginning to end these
songs are multifaceted they bring a lot
of different parts to the table and the
melodies that they have they just
escalate and escalate and escalate them
to the highest point of intensity before
the band sort of breaks off into
something else or sort of just ends the
song entirely but finding any
significant contrast or flow to these
songs as a group as an album is kind of
like trying to read into the finer
details of a portrait where the painter
decided to only use
shades of the color violet to create
this image nearly everything here reads
as the same color so it all kind of just
bleeds together no matter how many times
i revisit it you could take the songs on
this record and rearrange them into
really any order and you're gonna get
nearly the same vibe there are some
instrumental highlights on this lp
however the song foundations breaks
itself down to the point where it just
has this lone eerie guitar playing by
itself completely before the band breaks
back in with full instrumentation just
all guns blazing the song watcher in the
dark has one of the most fiery and
intense instrumental builds on the
entire lp and immediately after it
brings through one of the few keyboards
that appears in the track list here
there's also the song ashes which i wish
was a little bit longer because of how
beautiful and tender the keyboards are
on this particular track it's just kind
of a shame that this song sort of just
fizzles out and serves as nothing more
than a mere interlude in between what
just would have been yet another five
track album from pallbearer where all
the songs have a pretty uniform vibe
there's the closer like i said it has
some of the most menacing melodies on
the entire record and the ghost i used
to be was sort of a lead track from this
album to kind of promote toward its
release and while i do find some of the
melodies sticky i'm sort of wondering if
i'm gravitating toward this track or if
i'm remembering it just because it was
merely the first i was introduced to off
this lp though i will say there is a
part where the tempo and the riffs kind
of pick up on this track to a point
where the song kinda rocks there are
variations between these songs but the
differences again are so slight that the
tracks don't really work that
fantastically as a whole record from
beginning to end and this time the band
is working with nearly an hour's worth
of material and on their past album they
barely had 45 minutes of fresh varied
material again not a terrible lp in a
lot of ways a likable album but sort of
like a hot bath it just gets colder and
colder and colder the longer you sit in
it i'm feeling a strong five to a light
six on this thing tran position if
you've given this a listen what did you
think about it did you love it did you
hate it why what do you think i should
review next and that is it anthony
fantano paul bearer
forever
